quoteTime: About four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: I felt so badly, I left the office and went home. Ruth was out and I went into the library, planning to sleep for an hour or two before dinner.
title: The Marriage of William Durrant
author: Cummings, Ray, 1887-1957

quoteLast: the little band set out, loaded with all the skins in the caravan. The river was a ride of five or six hours distant; so that many hours of dreadful suspense must pass before the watchers left behind could know what was to be their fate.
title: The Animal Story Book
author: Lang, Andrew, 1844-1912 [Editor]; Ford, H. J. (Henry Justice), 1860-1941 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: On the morning of the 19th July it seemed as if a new deadlock was to bring the campaign to a standstill, for the two armies continued to face each other across the Guarena, Wellington hoping rather than expecting to be attacked, Marmont looking in vain for a weak point between Castrillo and Vallesa, where it would be worth while to try a forward thrust. While he was reconnoitring, his weary infantry got a much-needed rest. At
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , however, the whole French army was seen falling into column, and presently edged off southward till it lay between Tarazona and Cantalapiedra. Wellington thereupon made a corresponding movement, evacuating Castrillo to the north, and extending his line of battle beyond Vallesa to the south.
title: A history of the Peninsular War, Vol. 5, Oct. 1811-Aug. 31, 1812
author: Oman, Charles, 1860-1946

quoteLast: a rockaway drove up, stopped a few yards away, and a lady got out, accompanied by a little girl, and approached the man at the rock-pile. They were Mrs. Marsden and Roberta.
title: "That Old-Time Child, Roberta": Her Home-Life on the Farm
author: Sea, Sophie Fox

quoteFirst: James, Phillipps, Aylmer, myself, six of our men with firearms, the Koolookoo Sheik, and 15 of his men with spear and shield. We started off, on what _might_ prove to be our last journey,
quoteLast: And I think we shall all remember that silent ride of eight miles up the sandy river-bed of the Mareb to Abyssinia, shaded often by trees which thickly adorned the banks. We well knew, as we approached Abyssinia, that each bush may conceal an enemy, who might at any moment spring out on us unawares, and knowing this, each one clutched his rifle with a firm grip, ready for instant use, and determined to sell his life dearly if the worst came to the worst.
title:
Life in the Soudan
Adventures Amongst the Tribes, and Travels in Egypt, in 1881 and 1882
author: Williams, Josiah

quoteLast: of a day in August, and the third day since she had come home to her native town from Chicago, where she was employed.
title: Triumph of the Egg, and Other Stories
author: Anderson, Sherwood, 1876-1941

quoteFirst: This accident being disposed of, we emerged from this gorge, travelled over barren gravelly plains, dotted with pyramidal hills of the same material, whose {56} sides were belted with strata of coarse grey sand-stone.
quoteLast: , Jim halted beside a little brook, and pointing ahead, said, "Wat, ugh, u--gh;" by which I understood that the next water on our way was too far distant to be reached that night; and we encamped. The scenery to the west was very beautiful.
title: Farnham's Travels in the Great Western Prairies, etc., part 1, May 21-October 16, 1839
author: Farnham, Thomas Jefferson, 1804-1848; Thwaites, Reuben Gold, 1853-1913 [Editor]

quoteFirst: On this day all the rank and fashion can be seen between four and six driving up and down the Shoubra Road. This is lined by a splendid avenue of trees, which meet over-head, thus forming a delightful shade. It was now
quoteLast: ; I performed a hasty toilet and set off for a carriage drive down this road. I found it thronged with visitors and a goodly sprinkling of officers, amongst whom I saw the now famous Arabi Pacha.
title:
Life in the Soudan
Adventures Amongst the Tribes, and Travels in Egypt, in 1881 and 1882

quoteFirst: Having then fortunately arrived, by the blessing of the Lord, before the city of New York, on Saturday, the 23d day of September, we stepped ashore
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , in company with Gerrit, our fellow passenger, who would conduct us in this strange place. He had lived here a long time and had married his wife here, although she and his children were living at present at Zwol.
title: Journal of Jasper Danckaerts, 1679-1680

quoteFirst: On the 17th he took the former mess-house of the 32d regiment--a fortified building, and very strong.  “A most exciting, anxious day,” writes Lady Inglis in her diary.  “
quoteLast: , two strange officers walked through our yard, leading their horses”--and by that sign she knew that communication was established between the forces, that the relief was real, this time, and that the long siege of Lucknow was ended.
title: Following the Equator: A Journey Around the World
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon

title: It Is Never Too Late to Mend

quoteFirst: This perplexed the Americans, as was intended, and they pressed on towards the spot selected by the English officer for giving battle. This was reached
quoteLast: , and the attack was at once made by the Americans, who fired rapidly in platoons. The British line wavered, but a flanking fire from a body of Indians concealed in the woods settled the fate of the day against the Americans. They were thrown into confusion.
title: History for ready reference, Volume 5, Tunnage to Zyp and Supplement

quoteFirst: came with me for a day’s trip, taking a couple of boys and a montaria to return in. We had a fine wind, which took us across the great bays above Barra; and
quoteLast: we landed on a sandy beach, near which were a couple of cottages. Here Mr. S. found some handsome new flowering shrubs and trees, and I obtained five specimens of a small fish, a pacú new to me, so we both had work till supper-time; after which meal we hung our redes under the bushes as we best could, and passed an agreeable night.
title: A narrative of travels on the Amazon and Rio Negro,
author: Wallace, Alfred Russel, 1823-1913

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: we passed a hut. Of course every one, knowing we were in search of the Kellys, came out to see us. One of my men drew my attention to a man standing watching us, and told me he was one of the principal spies of the Kellys.
title: The Last of the Bushrangers: An Account of the Capture of the Kelly Gang
author: Hare, Francis Augustus

quoteFirst: Pushing ahead early the next day, Monday, June 30, the enemy was encountered about noon. The skirmishers were soon engaged, but the advance of our troops did not begin until
quoteLast: , and after we had suffered for two or more hours from a severe shelling. While under this severe fire and in line in the woods, in a swamp amidst brambles and vines, a shell from one of the enemy's guns burst immediately in our front and only a few feet away, scattering the fragments and shrapnel in our midst, one of which struck a man close by me, burying itself in a testament in his breast pocket, which thus saved his life.
title: The Story of a Confederate Boy in the Civil War
author: Johnston, David E. (David Emmons), 1845-1917; Cline, C. E. [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: On this morning Battery H moved with the corps toward Farmville, where it arrived
quoteLast: Our infantry skirmished with the enemy successfully, and passing through this beautiful little village camped on the heights beyond.
title: The History of Battery H First Regiment Rhode Island Light Artillery in the War to Preserve the Union 1861-1865
author: Fenner, Earl, 1841-
